node.title: Taylor Swift Copyright Lawsuit May Go to Trial, Judge Rules
node.alt: Taylor Swift accepted the Song of the Year award for “Shake It Off” at the 2015 iHeartRadio Music Awards. She is accused of stealing lyrics from the 2001 song “Playas Gon’ Play.”
node.description: Taylor Swift is accused of stealing lyrics in her hit song “Shake It Off” from the song “Playas Gon’ Play” by the R&B trio 3LW.
node.content: ["A federal judge on Thursday denied a request by Taylor Swift to throw out a copyright infringement suit accusing her of stealing lyrics in her 2014 hit song \u201cShake It Off,\u201d and ordered that the case could go to trial.", "The lawsuit was filed by Sean Hall and Nathan Butler, the writers of the 2001 song \u201cPlayas Gon\u2019 Play\u201d by the R&B group 3LW. A trial would test whether parts of Ms. Swift\u2019s song, including versions of the phrases \u201cplayers gonna play\u201d and \u201chaters gonna hate,\u201d are similar enough to the earlier song to meet the legal threshold for copyright infringement.", "Judge Michael Fitzgerald, of the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, denied Ms. Swift\u2019s request for a summary judgment on Thursday. The case will go to trial unless a settlement is reached.", "In the decision, Judge Fitzgerald said Ms. Swift\u2019s legal team had made \u201ca strong closing argument\u201d but had failed to show that the issues in the case could not be resolved by a jury.", "Other defendants in the case include the producers Max Martin and Shellback; the music publishers Sony and Kobalt; Big Machine Label Group; and Universal Music Group.", "Lawyers for Ms. Swift and the other defendants did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Friday.", "Marina Bogorad, a lawyer for the songwriters, said in an email, \u201cOur clients are extremely satisfied with this decision, especially because it reinforces the notion that their unique self-expression based on the deeply rooted cultural heritage cannot be simply snatched away without proper attribution.\u201d", "The songwriters first filed the lawsuit against Ms. Swift in September 2017. Judge Fitzgerald dismissed the case in 2018, but it was returned to his court by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.", "The lyrics under review in Ms. Swift\u2019s song include \u201cCause the players gonna play, play, play, play, play/ And the haters gonna hate, hate, hate, hate, hate.\u201d These lines are being tested against \u201cPlayas, they gon\u2019 play/ And haters, they gonna hate,\u201d from the song by 3LW, an all-female R&B trio popular in the early 2000s.", "In his 2018 original ruling, the judge said the lyrics under debate were \u201ctoo brief, unoriginal, and uncreative\u201d to be protected under the Copyright Act.", "\u201cIn the early 2000s, popular culture was adequately suffused with the concepts of players and haters to render the phrases \u2018playas \u2026 gonna play\u2019 or \u2018haters \u2026 gonna hate\u2019 standing on their own, no more creative than \u2018runners gonna run,\u2019 \u2018drummers gonna drum,\u2019 or \u2018swimmers gonna swim,\u2019\u201d he wrote in his February 2018 order.", "George Howard, a professor of music business management at Berklee College of Music, described the system for testing music copyright as imperfect and said that, in many cases, labels and publishers will settle if they think there is any chance they could lose a case.", "Several high-profile cases have tested the music copyright standards in court in recent years, in some cases creating concern that artists will face a flood of lawsuits.", "After a federal jury concluded that Robin Thicke\u2019s 2013 song \u201cBlurred Lines\u201d had copied elements of Marvin Gaye\u2019s \u201cGot to Give It Up,\u201d musicians and record labels warned that the precedent could have a chilling effect on artists.", "But in 2020, some felt the tide was changing after Led Zeppelin prevailed in a copyright suit in October of that year. Months before, a federal judge had vacated an earlier decision that Katy Perry\u2019s hit \u201cDark Horse\u201d had infringed on the copyright of a Christian rap song."]
